context: The DAC was constructed from a steel frame covered with a 200 μm ETFE foil. It is 1.8 m in height and its volume accounts for around 10 m3. An adjustable air blower was operated at 400 ± 20 m3/h. Determination of benzene and MTBE air concentrations was performed using active sampling onto sorbent tubes (150 mg Tenax TA® plus 100 mg Chromosorb106®) according to EPA Method TO-17 (U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 1999) at the inlet and outlet of the DAC. Duplicate samples were taken hourly with a sampling rate of 25 ml/min. The inflow and outflow groundwater contaminant concentrations were monitored simultaneously. More detailed information regarding design, setup and function of the dynamic air chamber will be presented in a separate manuscript (Reiche et al., submitted for publication).Sampling procedure Groundwater at the inflow and effluent from the two systems was monitored periodically (2–4 times a month).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 2-methoxy-2-methylpropane is not directly mentioned but is implied as a potential contaminant being monitored in the air alongside benzene and MTBE. Tenax TA® is used as a sorbent material for active sampling of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) like 2-methoxy-2-methylpropane. The relationship is based on Tenax's role in capturing and analyzing air samples for VOCs, including 2-methoxy-2-methylpropane, but no specific interaction or detailed discussion of their relationship is provided.
